FRIDAY, OCTOBER 22, 1886.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.
PUBLISHED BY
J. D. MAVEETY
AT PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.
PRICES—Single copies 10 cents each.
No issue will be published in the paper. Notices local &c., in order. Notices intended for publication should be inserted until further notice.
All letters to be addressed to the Proprietor.
J. D. MAVEETY, Proprietor.

THIS PAPER may be had at the offices of Mr. ROBERTSON & Co., Newspapers, Prince Albert, N.W.T.; Mr. HUTCHISON, Proprietor.
NEW YORK.

SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

St. Albans' and St. Paul's Churches.

11 o'clock—Service in both churches, and 7 p.m.—Sunday School 3 p.m.—Catechism in charge of Mr. B. A. Wilson and Mr. C. Cunningham, Theological Students of Dominion College.

Our Lord's Supper will be preached, and a service, when home, at St. Paul's in the morning, and at St. Albans in the evening.

St. Catharine's.

11:30 a.m.—Rev. Canon Flett, R.D.

St. Paul's.

1 p.m.—Rev. Canon Flett, R.D.

St. John's.

10:30 a.m.—Mr. Macdonald.

St. James'.

3 p.m.—Rev. Mr. Macdonald.

St. Anne's, R. Catholic.

10:30 a.m. and 3 p.m.—Rev. Peter Dominick.

St. Peter's.

11 a.m. and 5 p.m.—Rev. Mr. McWilliam.

Methodist Church.

Rev. Mr. McReynolds will preach at regular services at 11 a.m., 3 p.m. and 7 p.m. every Sunday excepting Wednesdays and Thursdays evenings at 8 p.m. Rev. Mr. Willis in charge.

FRIDAY, OCT. 22, 1886.

THE H. R. RAILWAY.

Those people of Manitoba and those who have been engaged in the building of ordinary narrow-gauge roads to navigate the Hudson's Straits and Bay, the actual completion of the construction of the Great Northern railway cannot fail to be encouraging in the extreme. It is the realization of their dreams and aspirations. But while it is an augury of better times for Manitoba, and Winnipeg as its capital, it is also the best times for the North-West, and the great Saskatchewan country, the fairest portion of the Canadian North-west, in particular.

Not many years ago the people of the east and south imagined the Great Lake to be the only route suitable for civilized people. Time, and a very short time, has proved that a civilized man can travel by rail through this country, and the explosion of the idea that Hudson's Straits and Bay could be used as a navigable waterway has brought the North-West not only out of the pale of civilization, but will, with the completion of the H. R. Railway, show that the North-West, instead of being far removed from civilization as represented in the east, are closer to the markets of the world than any eastern and southern communities.

From forty to sixty miles are expected to be completed this fall, and the most of the line will be heard at the Grand Rapids, if not far beyond. Just what it will mean to the commerce of this country, and the expansion of the idea that Hudson's Straits and Bay could be used as a navigable waterway has brought the North-West not only out of the pale of civilization, but will, with the completion of the H. R. Railway, show that the North-West, instead of being far removed from civilization as represented in the east, are closer to the markets of the world than any eastern and southern communities.

The QUEBEC ELECTIONS.

If the late handsome Chief of the Metis, Mr. David Lepine, is to be trusted, the election of Mr. Mercier, Liberal Edgeworth, is in a position to look towards, downwards, especially if diagonally on the line which he has marked out for himself. If the Quebec election has been marred, there are some people who are not satisfied with the result. They say that what they would do if the North-West were an independent State of Canada, we must admit that the growth of our legislative bodies have been marred by the same defect.

Besides, we have been granted a representation in the House of Commons after the manner of the old Roman Senate, whose progress has been marred, there are some people who are not satisfied with the result. They say that what they would do if the North-West were an independent State of Canada, we must admit that the growth of our legislative bodies have been marred by the same defect.

ABOUT AN EVEN THING.

If the late handsome Chief of the Metis, Mr. David Lepine, is to be trusted, the election of Mr. Mercier, Liberal Edgeworth, is in a position to look towards, downwards, especially if diagonally on the line which he has marked out for himself. If the Quebec election has been marred, there are some people who are not satisfied with the result. They say that what they would do if the North-West were an independent State of Canada, we must admit that the growth of our legislative bodies have been marred by the same defect.

NOTICE.

SCHOOL HOUSE.

SATURDAY, OCT. 31st, 1886.

The vote will be open from 10 a.m. until 6 p.m.

The qualification of voters is expressed in the following words:

"I do solemnly swear that I am a bona fide elector of the Riding of Prince Albert, District No. 3 of the North-West Territories, and that I have paid the sum of Six Thousand Two Hundred Dollars to the Receiver General of Canada, in equal annual instalments from date of receipt thereof, and that I have paid the sum of Five Thousand Dollars for the purpose of purchasing land in the North-West Territories for the purpose of farming, and that I have paid the sum of Four Hundred dollars for the purpose of purchasing land in the North-West Territories for the purpose of farming, and that I have paid the sum of Two Hundred dollars for the purpose of purchasing land in the North-West Territories for the purpose of farming."

A vote on the above will be taken at the

SCHOOL HOUSE.

HE GOT THE BOOGEY.

Some time ago a man who gave his name as Smith—a name most of us have heard before—bore a halberd at Troy station in the olden days. On arriving at the ferry he demanded to be taken across the river, where the ferryman stood waiting for him. The ferryman refused, saying that he was not going to take any man across the river who did not pay for the privilege. Smith then took out a gun and threatened to shoot the ferryman if he did not take him across. The ferryman then called for help, and a crowd gathered around them. Smith then disappeared into the crowd, and was never seen again.

MOORE & MACDOWALL
TERRITORIAL NEWS.

The Edmonton Bulletin, Sept. 29th, says:

Mr. Lloyd W. G. Hinton, W. J. H. and W. B. Wilson arrived from Pitts-

field Wednesday. The H.B. post has been re-established; there are now three post

masters serving: Rev. Mr. Quimby, church of England missionary, is leaving for his old country and has sold his

house at Lac La Croix to Mr. Murray, in-

tending to go into business. A large quantity of provisions for the new telegraph line to Battleford

have been sent by Mr. Murray. Indian department buildings have been erected at Onion lake and a

Roman Catholic mission established. Frog Lake has been abandoned.

Holbrook, the post-office on the Bow river trail at the head of the Battle-

River, has been closed by Mr. J. A. Jay, post master.

J. Walter, south side, had a yield of

900 pounds of grain.

The fruit trees introduced here last fall

and spring by A. E. Blake have not de-

veloped done well, having grown from two to four feet high.

A. W. R. Macleay, agent for the

Confederation Life Association, arrived on

Monday's stage.

Edward Cunningham, brother of S.

Cunningham, M. N. W. C., Mr. Albert,

was recently admitted into the order of

Oblates at London, England. The Rev.

George Mulock, brother of Rev. Peter La-

combe, Rev. Peter Cunningham was elec-

ted by the priesthood of the Ottawa

College.

Misses Pibon and Moody returned

from their trip to take Attawapiskat

Saturday last. They brought back a

quantity of furs, several of which

have been purchased rich in silver and

others in gold. They also brought

specimens of fish.

The Battleford Herald, Sept. 28th, says—

The fever continues its ravages, several

new cases having been in the course of

the week added to the list of victims of

the horrible Inspectors Wilson is a victim.

The worst section was that of Co-

lumbia, where the fever has been

affected since his illness. The earlier

sufferers are slowly improving.

Capt. J. A. Simpson and Capt. Rich-

mond, who have been attacked, have already

been attacked by the fever.

The Medicine Hat Times of Oct. 5th, says—

Capt. Collins, the policeman who died

last Friday morning while attend-

ing the funeral being a military one, and

the band taking part.

A man named James Patton was arrested

in town last night, charged with steal-

ing a horse from McBride. He was

brought before the court, and Judge

Nash, who was requested to sign the

paper before Col. McLeod at the next

court.

The Medicine Hat Times of Oct. 5th, says—

About twenty men are at work entag-

ling the stock yards at this point for the

adjoining cattle market.

The Methodists are erecting a preaching

pole on the lots occupied by the church.

The sheep shipped from here last week

by Messrs. Holmes and Hillebrand were

sold in Winnipeg for six in the live-

stock market.

Major George Strange and soldiers

were sent away in the ambulance bed

and heavy after all the sections tried

he has led.

The Calgary Herald, Oct. 5th, says—

On Monday morning a fire broke out

in the old buildings of the Blackfoot

Agency, which completely demolished

the building and destroyed the contents

of the same and burnt at least in the

buildings and left them for a few minutes

to speak to one of the other employ-

ees, who thought he was going to

smoke issued from them. He immedi-

ately gave the alarm, but the fire had

already spread through the premises,

as a huge flame immediately

burst forth. He rushed into the building

for a second time. He had a very

narrow escape, just getting outside when

he got back to the spot, but he was

badly burned about the body and

hands. On Monday night he was brought

to Calgary by Dr. Graham dressed

his burns. An Indian was seen run-

ning out of the burning at the same time

and it is thought he dropped a match

in the bushes.

From the Red River Press we learn

that the Sioux Indians have begun the

Marie River raids upon the settlers of Ten O'Clock

Springs, taking a great deal from Emma

Beverly, Mrs. Murray and Mrs. Murray. Up-

til this raid was five nights ago. A

short time afterwards they attempted to steal

the horses of Davis & Kennedy in broad

daylight, but being discovered only got

away with two. It seems that the

smallest amount of some weeks ago,

a detachment of cavalry was camped on

the Marie River, and on hearing of their

proximity did nothing they wished. Mr.

Price says this sort of thing is getting

more frequent and more serious. A large

quantity of stores have been lost, and in fact

there is nothing the Indians do not do

except take the life of settlers.

The wheat harvest is now coming completion.

The season has been particularly fa-

vorable done in the mountain and

plains sections, which have given

extraordinary prices. The wheat has

been of the best grade, with good

quality.

Another grain of $20 has been donated

for the finest baby under one year, if

born in marriage license ought to be

given.

John Clarke, of Crookston, had seven

males and females selected from his corn-

field, and a prize of $100 for their recovery.

THE FIRST SOD.

COMMENCEMENT OF WORK ON THE H. B.

RAILWAY AT RESERVATION

October, 1869.

(From the Mountains.)

Actual work on the Hudson's Bay Rail-

way has been commenced, and from

this day forward the construction of

work promised to become of the

greatest conceivable advantage to Man-

itoba and Western Canada.

The first sod

was turned on the section just north of

Frank Park, but without any particular

demonstration. Hon. Mr. Neppin and

the prominent provincial citizens were

present. An

INTERESTING PROCESSION

passed down Main street early Saturday

morning, consisting of a number of military

guards, wagons, road sweepers, etc.

drawn by 22 teams of mules and eight

oxen. The train was drawn back by

policemen, implements, and tools, includ-

ing axeholds, and accompanying them

was a large gang of men. The entire

train proceeded into the woods near

Main, and went out at the starting point

of the Hudson's Bay Railway, prepara-

tions for the laying of the first sod on

Monday morning. The appearance of

such a large force dispelled the doubts

which existed regarding the practicability

and feasibility of the H. B. scheme, and many

smiling countenances were noticed and

expressed satisfaction at the large number of citizens who wit-

nessed the march past. As the proce-

ssion reached the store of Mr. J. H. Hay,

the chief engineer, Mr. Hay stepped

forward with a number of prominent

members of the front town with a small heraldic flag, and it was at once attached to the

front of the procession.

Mr. Hugh Sutherland went west this

morning to interview the municipal authori-

ties of the town of Fort Saskatchewan.

Upon the arrival at the east terminus

this morning was C. F. Henderson, who

in addition to his duties as railway

engineer and superintendent of con-

struction on the Hudson's Bay Railway.

It is understood that petitions will be

sent to the Hon. Mr. Neppin and others

to place a bill granting a

bonus to the town before the people to be

authorized. As expected, the town stated,

but with the growing feeling in favor of

offering every assistance and encourage-

ment to the road, a handsome amount

will be voted to be raised.

Ladies (to a young woman):

Have you ever appeared as witness in

a suit before?

Young Woman (blushing): "Yes, yes,

sir, of course."

Ladies: "Please state to the jury

what it still was."

Young woman (with more confidence):

"It was a man's wedding, attended by

myself and informed myself with a lovely

blue dress and a parasol."

Judge (jumping violently): "Order in

the court." - Kansas City Journal.
